title: What are some actions that are universally morally wrong? - Quora

response.answer_text: To say just the 10 Commandments would be a vast understatement when there are over 600 laws in the Bible. The 10 Commandments are merely a summary of those 600+ laws and in the New Testament Christ even summed up the 10 Commandments further into just two: Love God with all your heart and love thy neighbor as thy self. In other words, if you loved God then you’d be obedient to him and if you loved your neighbor you‘d keep the commandments - I know, it’s redundant. Loving God literally means you’re abiding by the laws (1 John 3:4 Love = Obedience). Not coveting your neighbors wife is showing love for your neighbor; not stealing your neighbors possessions is showing love for your neighbor; not forcibly taking him into slavery and making him work without pay is showing love; not depriving him of a living, not charging him interest, not leaving him lamb in a ditch when you have the ability to help it. All the commandments are geared towards doing what’s right for humanity and when you break one you break the fundamental barriers of morality and then chaos ensues. The Bible is universal moral law, and, no, it’s not bias.

Morality depends on life. Whatever benefits it is good, whatever harms it is bad (or as Ayn Rand writes, “evil”). Therefore, killing is the ultimate wrong. Following that, initiating physical violence against individuals is wrong, the level depending on how badly hurt they are and how long they’re forced to endure their suffering. For example, initiating violence by blowing someone’s limbs off is worse than punching them (provided it doesn’t kill of seriously harm them). Likewise, compelling individuals to act against their will is also wrong. For example, forcing them to do work they don’t want (slavery), or ‘disappearing’ them if they publicly disagree with the government.
